feed.title: Ellen DeGeneres Helps Ont. Girl's Quest for Organ Donation Awareness
feed.subtitle: Helene Campbell's one-woman crusade to raise organ donor awareness hit another high note Thursday when she made an unexpected appearance on Ellen DeGeneres's popular daytime talk show.

link.title: Helene Campbell

link.Abstract: Ellen DeGeneres said she was "proud and happy" that retail store J.C. Penney had stood by her in the face of a conservative anti-gay campaign.
link.title: Ellen breaks silence on furor over J.C. Penney gig

link.title: Watch Kristen Bell's Adorable Meltdown Over Sloths

content.div:
OTTAWA — Helene Campbell's one-woman crusade to raise organ donor awareness hit another high note Thursday when she made an unexpected appearance on Ellen DeGeneres's popular daytime talk show.

The 20-year-old Ottawa woman, who has been in Toronto for the past month awaiting a double-lung transplant, received a surprise on-air call from DeGeneres via Skype. Campbell, who had sent DeGeneres a video urging her to use her celebrity to publicize the cause, was told the show's website might want to post her video, and to merely to expect a call from one of the website's technicians.

"My mom knew about it," an excited Campbell said afterwards. "Oh, my goodness, my mom lied to me."

In the six-and-a-half-minute clip that aired Thursday, Campbell, upon realizing that it was actually DeGeneres on the line, is seen calling out to her mother, "Mom, can you turn up my oxygen?"

"It was really exciting," she said later. "I couldn't breathe. I can't believe I didn't cry. I'm so overwhelmed and in shock."

She added that she never expected to be on the show. "I just hoped she would see the video and be inspired to say something (about organ donation) on the show."

On Feb. 9, in response to a call by DeGeneres for viewers to send in videos of themselves dancing, Campbell made one asking DeGeneres to use her celebrity to raise awareness of organ donation. Campbell dubbed her campaign "It's DeGeneres thing to do."

"I love dancing, like you do," she said in that video, "and without getting a lung transplant, I won't be able to do it again."

In October, her lung capacity was measured at 24 per cent. Recent tests have seen that number drop to 21 per cent.

In Thursday's segment, DeGeneres told Campbell: "What's amazing about this video . . . I get a lot of people that want to meet me or want me to do something, but you actually are sending this out not to help yourself, because you're on a list and it's going to happen when it's going to happen, but you want to help others, and you asked me to help get the message across, so I want to help you do that."

DeGeneres added that she is an organ donor.

DeGeneres also said that she was going to send Campbell to the Toronto premiere of film The Hunger Games, and invited Campbell and her mother to Burbank, Calif., to appear on the show after Helene has had her transplant.

"I want to meet you in person," DeGeneres said. "I'd love to hang out with you backstage, and we're going to dance together. We are going to dance together, you and me.

"You're an amazing, amazing young woman."

Since learning last fall of her need for a double-lung transplant, Campbell, who has idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis — a condition that hardens the lungs and reduces elasticity — had been sending daily emails to DeGeneres.

"I've been a fan of hers since before Finding Nemo came out," Campbell said, referring to DeGeneres's role as Dory in the 2003 Disney film.

Campbell began her awareness campaign in January, when she convinced Justin Bieber to tweet about organ donation to his millions of Twitter followers.

She has also been approached by organizers of The Torch of Life, a worldwide organ donation-awareness campaign, to speak, via Skype, with students at schools across Ontario.

"If my health permits it," notes Campbell.

For more information, visit alungstory.ca and beadonor.ca.

link.Abstract: J.C. Penney Co Inc said on Friday it fully backs its partnership with chat show host Ellen DeGeneres.
